The NSU,BRAC and IUB bickering is officially over, and the post deleted. 

You know why the best universities in the United States demand so much information from you? It's because they want to try to best understand you in person, so that they know if you're the BEST FIT for their college or if their college is best suited for you. While there isn't as much diversity in policies, course structure and faculty quality in Bangladeshi universities, it is completely up to the individual to decide which university you want to go to. There isn't an OBJECTIVE RANKING that ranks NSU over BRAC or BRAC over IBA and what not. Remember it isn't MIT vs NSU here.

A LOT(and I can't emphasize this enough) depends on the student himself. I mean, look at the Mystery Box challenge in MasterChef- do all the contestants create the same beautiful dish using the SAME ingredients given to them? No! On the contrary, everyone produces a distinctive dish of distinct taste. Hell, there are at times even multiple winners- which suggest that WINNING itself is diverse. Similarly, 2 students going to X university will utilize the SAME(or similar) facilities differently. Yet 2 students from 2 different universities (hence facilities) can succeed in their own individual goals!

Thus, please stop making such petty, baseless arguments that will only confuse the inquirer even more. 

To the prospective student- believe me it is IMMENSELY up to YOU how you make use of the Mystery Box; regardless of what you get, you must believe that YOU CAN COOK A GREAT DISH.

EDEXCEL A Levels Economics tips - the Big Daddy of them all:

The issue that most students consistently face in the mocks is firstly, time management, and secondly, framing the answer properly. I can't help you with time management, that is a personal issue that you guys MUST practice to deal with. Economics is a race against time, not just in A Levels but for later on if you want to pursue it in higher levels as well. And it's always going to be about writing - a LOT of writing. It almost makes me not miss Literature, that's how much we have to write, and how detailed and nuanced our writings have to be. A Levels sets the absolute basic foundations for that. 

Let's begin with Section A. For AS, Section A is MCQs. Don't get lazy - I know there are ways around this, but writing the explanations in the proper way will help YOU in the long run. One mark for definition, one mark for explanation, one mark for analysis/application. What does that mean? So for instance, let's say the question says that the rate of inflation fell from 4% to 1%, which of the following is true. The correct answer is that this means that the purchasing power of money has fallen (if you don't understand why this is the right option, please comment below, I'll explain it in details :) ). For the first mark, define EITHER inflation OR disinflation, not both. And please learn the exact definitions, I cannot stress this enough. The reason why we ask you to learn the exact definitions is that when you try to write it in your own words you often mess up the true meaning. It's easy enough, there's not much to learn, I feared memorization my entire life; if I can do it, so can you. For the second mark, explain what is happening: prices rise, value of money falls because one unit of currency buys fewer goods. For the third mark, relate back to the question, fall from 4% to 1% means that prices are still rising because the rate is still positive, but at a slower rate. For more tips on how to get this right - practice the question papers, read the mark schemes, that's how you learn. 

Additionally, if it is mathematical, there's a sure-shot scope for full marks if you guys get the right option. 1 mark for definition and 2 marks for showing the steps of the calculation. Important note: you know those questions that show the multiple shifting of the curves, AD and SRAS? You need to explain why AD shifted (1 mark) why SRAS shifted (1 mark) AND the effect on price level and quantity output as a result (1 mark). Most students miss out on this last part and write definitions instead - no marks for definition here. 

If you're truly stumped, write rejection points. However, that's what I call being lazy, and I personally don't encourage this unless it's a last resort - messes up with how your brain works in terms of framing answers. Nevertheless, DO add rejection points just as a safety measure, sometimes even if you miss out on explanation and write 3 rejection points, you still get the mark. 

Section A for A2 is slightly more complicated, but manageable none the same. To begin with, understand the mark allocations. For Unit 3, you have 20 marks for each question. Which means that you need to have roughly 12 marks for explanation and 8 marks for evaluation. The break down of these vary, which is what makes it difficult to understand what to write - but remember that you KNOW most of these things, don't get nervous. Some answers have a lot of definitions (such as questions about cost curves, shut down point, etc) which need to be written as explanations. Others such as the ones on mergers have a lot that you can explain - don't waste a lot of time in writing definitions for those. Write around 5 to 6 explanation points, and 4 to 5 evaluations. Also, I keep repeating this over and over again, but this is important - please don't just state the points, you need to explain them. My friends and I had a running joke during A Levels that we have to write around 320 lines for just 80 marks in Economics, because writing 4 lines earns us 1 mark. Cue jealousy for Physics and Chemistry where there are questions where just writing the keywords gains you marks. 

For Unit 4, the first question is 15 marks and 24 marks for the second. The second answer normally has around 14 marks for explanation, 10 for evaluation and 1 for a conclusive statement. The first is around 8 marks for explanation, 6 for evaluations and 1 for a conclusive statement. However, this is not strictly maintained and once more, depends on the answer. Make sure that these are the bare minimum that you cover though. For the first question in Unit 4, have around 4 to 5 different explanation points, and for the second have around 6 to 7 different ones. Once again - this is not strictly maintained, if some explanations are very well developed, that works too. Read the mark schemes and examiner's reports to get a gist of what I mean. It's not the quantity of the points that matter but rather the quality - so even if you write 10 explanation points with no proper development, you will get less marks than someone who wrote around 3 to 4 explanation points that was beautifully developed and linked with each other and back to the question, relating more with real life scenarios. Try not to be too bookish guys, the examiners know what the book says, most of them wrote it themselves. xD This is an essay and this is economics, your analysis matters, this is not something you can or should attempt to memorise.

Moving on to Section B, it is relatively simpler. For AS, it is ABSOLUTELY straightforward. There's a MAX of 2 marks for definitions, 2 marks for diagram if it's relevant, MAX two marks for data reference. I stress on the MAX because candidates get carried away and spend way too long on definitions and data references. No matter which unit or what the question is, NEVER more than 2 marks for data reference. They expect you to build your explanations and analysis around the information in the extract, but don't just quote the extract guys, max 2 marks for quoting figures. So for instance, if the extract talks about collusion and there's evidence of whistleblowing, the examiners will be expecting game theory and whistleblowing incorporated in your evaluations and explanations. Remember when your teacher said "you don't have to write ALL the points, write ANY 3"? Yeah, that's the examiners dropping mad hints that you'll basically not score Level 3 or 4 marks (i.e. not more than 70% of the marks) unless you specifically talk about those particular points in your answer. The same applies for Unit 3 and 4 too. However, what puts the 2 in A2 is the fact that you are taught many more theories in A2 (Harrod-Domar model, Lewis model, Prebische-Singer hypothesis, Laffer curve, etc). Fancy names, basically, they need you to use and refer to the fancy names.The mark allocation stays the same, just go through any random mark scheme from the recent years and it should be clear to you.

Some concluding tips - if you haven't already, start solving the question papers and read the mark schemes and examiner's reports. Don't just read, practice WRITING the answers to questions in the papers and time yourself. Give yourself less time to finish it than the allocated time. When you're at home, you're not stressed and you're comfortable, your brain works better, so you should need (and practice to need) less time. During the exam and the mock, more often than not I've personally had situations where I blanked out completely. It's therefore important to train your brain to finish the papers with time to spare where you can include the freaking out part during the exam. 

And finally, relax guys, you got this. You've studied the whole year. You KNOW these stuff. You just need to show the examiners all that you know. All the best wishes.

Antonie van Leeuwenhoek: The unlikely scientist

One of the most intriguing stories in the history of science is that of the Dutch draper Antonie van Leeuwenhoek, who owing to his curiosity and diligence became the "father" of the field of microbiology.

Hailing from a family of tradesmen, having  no fortune and receiving no higher education, van Leeuwenhoek made a name for himself as one of the most in demand drapers in the city of Delft. In order to aid his craft and be able to pick out the finest of fabrics, he invented a form of compound microscope which would allow him to observe the binding of his fabrics in more detail. 

One day, he decided to explore his garden using the tiny invention and what he discovered was tiny moving microorganisms,which he originally referred to as animalcules. His works along with the works of Robert Hooke during that period led to the formation of the field of microbiology.

A Level Economics tips:

Guys. Please read the question properly. For the love of all things holy. If the question asks you to examine/assess the effects of a depreciation DO NOT WRITE ABOUT THE FACTORS WHICH CAUSE THE CURRENCY TO DEPRECIATE. 

A factor of currency depreciation (i.e. NOT WHAT THE QUESTION ASKED FOR):
Higher foreign interest rate causes hot money outflow, the supply of domestic currency increases in the international currency market, leading to a depreciation.

Effect of currency depreciation (i.e. what the question actually asked for):
A currency depreciation makes exports cheaper and imports expensive, thus exports rise, could improve the balance of payment current account. On the other hand, import of raw materials becomes expensive, could lead to cost-push inflation, etc. etc.

The researchers report that(40) light from quasars showing the magnesium(II) line was more strongly polarized than light from other quasars in the sample. The interpretation: [that] light did(45) indeed pass through regular galaxies and that it likely acquired its polarization in the process.

Hey everyone! As the January 2017 exams are only 2 months away and the mocks are running, I have got a couple of questions on how to improve marks in Accounting AS specially, for the new specification. So below are some tips and tricks and methods. Hope the students find this helpful:  

1. I have gone through the new specification and have collected information that marks for theory have been fixed this time. Hence, work very well on the formats first. This is important because regardless of anything this carries the most marks.

2. In order to improve you don't really have to memorize everything. I would suggest to first go through every single format and get to know them. Afterwards, figure out how a transaction istaking place and what effect it has on the final accounts. Once you have done that, you will not only answer the maths properly but score more marks in evaluations. 

3. For Accounting AS a chapter most students I have seen to avoid is Ratio Analysis. However, I would recommend students to answer it as it requires you to just use the formulae and theory. If you are good at theory this can help you score a lot marks.

4. For those of you who are worried about making constant silly mistakes, go through MS. It really helps! Going through the MS gives you an idea on answering and mark allocation.           

5. The new mark allocation system, or the Assessment objective system that's worrying many students. What it actually checks is how well informed you are about accounting. So you need to linkchapters and concepts to score marks in the highest band.
                                                     
6. Theory. Marks for theory in this specification have been fixed which I believe is around 50. This in my opinion is beneficial as you know exactly how much to need to study and answer. To do well in theory I suggest students to go through them once frequently and understanding them. In this way it will be really easy for you toanswer evaluations. 

7. Find out what works best for you. Make your own patterns, categorize chapters in sections; for example, good - needs practice - need to learn properly - least likely to answer. This will really make things easier and organized for you, instead of looking like a huge syllabus.     

8. Lastly, evaluations. For evaluations you need to have a good idea about relations between transactions and profit/loss and capital and ratios. And it is really easy to do, all you have to do is know what ratio measures what, and whether a transaction is debit or credit. That's it! . This is applicable to every single chapter as evaluation maybe incorporated in any question. 

This is all for now, if anyone has any further questions please comment below. Hope this is going to be helpful 😀😀😁

*Extra words and phrases #Olevel students should avoid writing in #SectionC*

1) First of all –First is first, thus, you don’t need "of all". Ex: First of all, I didn’t tell Morjina your name. Better: First, I didn’t tell Morjina your name.

2) General public – Let’s not use “general public”(seems like army designation) Ex: The portable bathrooms are for the general public. Better: The portable bathrooms are for the public.

3) Future plans – We always plan for future so skip writing “future plans”. Ex: What are your future plans for college? Better: What are your plans for college?

4) Frozen ice – Redundant phrase. You don’t need frozen. Ex: Ben Stokes fell through the frozen ice. Better: Ben Stokes fell through the ice.

5) Final conclusion –Final destination may change even at the last moment but conclusion always comes at last. Ex: He came to a final conclusion that he hated his job. Better: He came to a conclusion that he hated his job. Best: He concluded that he hated his job.

The Hitchhiker's guide to O'Levels English Language! :D

 After the O'levels results came out this August, many of the future O'level candidates were asking what should they do to obtain an A grade in English. Well I'm not an expert on this, but I can give you some advice which can help you to obtain the best possible marks in each of the three sections depending on your potential.

 Section A consists of 2, sometimes 3, passages followed by some questions regarding those passages. The first thing you should do is to read these passages fully without even looking at the questions. After you're done, read the questions carefully and try to understand what the examiner wants. Then go back to that part of the passage from where you can find your answer and underline it neatly with a pencil. While answering the question, if the question doesn't mention the phrase 'write in your own word,' you should directly copy the answer word by word from the passage. If the question is to be answered in more than one point, look at the mark of that question and answer accordingly. For example, if the question is for 2 marks, your answer must have at least 2 points. If you follow these steps, you can secure good marks provided you can answer without making any grammatical errors. Also, improving your knowledge on vocabulary is important in understanding the nuances of various questions.

 Then comes Section B, Directed Writing. Here they will ask you to write an application or a short extract from a diary or a journal using the facts taken from the given passages in Section A. PLEASE NOTE- DO NOT USE ANY FACT IF THEY ARE NOT MENTIONED IN THE PASSAGE. They won’t give credits for such facts even if they are true. You must mention about 22-26 points from the passages to secure the best possible marks.
 There is an easy way, or should I say a 'hack,' to make a good impression about yourself to the examiner in this section. What you have to do is to write down the facts/points required according to the question in the first page of the Section B answer sheet and neatly cross them out with single line over the whole page but make sure they are still readable. I've uploaded a picture, here’s the link: https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B8jBQn7LrruzWlJqa0JVNVRmYjg/view?usp=sharing. So, while checking your paper, the examiner will surely notice this page and know how many and which points you've taken from the passages for this section. Thus, it'll be easier for them to check that section and can have a clear idea about your answer. The rest depends on your writing skills.

 Now for the final one, Section C. One thing I must mention about this section is that, the examiner will never expect a 'Shakespeare-styled' writings from you. So try to write your essay in a simple and logical manner. You may think if you use lots of esoteric words, you can impress your examiner. But there is a high chance for a student of this standard to mess up and not using the acceptable synonyms which will result in losing marks. 
 Yes, you can use correct synonyms and write a great essay without losing much marks but you should avoid writing boring lengthy sentences and in the process, commit grammatical errors. Try to make your story interesting using simple languages rather than a complicated one filled up with 'bombastic' vocabularies. Similar guideline is applicable for argumentative writings too.

 On a realistic note, the January candidates still have two months before their exam. Try to practice as many question papers as possible and do get them checked by your teachers. As with everything, Google is your best friend to find sample essays from around the world. 

 Best of luck!

What was #Brexit? Why was it so important? What would its impact be on world economy?

WHAT DID #BREXIT MEAN?
It was a word that had become as a shorthand way of saying the UK leaving the European Union (EU) – merging the words Britain and exit to get Brexit.

WHAT HAPPENED?
A referendum was held on Thursday, 23 June, to decide whether Britain should leave or remain in the European Union.

WHAT IS THE EUROPEAN UNION?
The European Union – often known as the EU – is an economic and political partnership involving 28 European countries. It began after World War Two to foster economic co-operation, with the idea that countries which trade together are more likely to avoid going to war with each other.
It has since grown to become a “single market” allowing goods and people to move around, basically as if the member states were one country. It has its own currency, the euro, which is used by 19 of the member countries, its own parliament and it now sets rules in a wide range of areas – including on the environment, transport, consumer rights and even things like mobile phone charges.
With GDP of more than $18,000 bn and a population of more than 500 m, it is the biggest economy in the world. Member states remain the most powerful actors within the EU — with Angela Merkel, German chancellor, the bloc’s most powerful leader.

WHAT IS A REFERENDUM?
A referendum is basically a vote in which everyone (or nearly everyone) of voting age can take part, normally giving a “Yes” or “No” answer to a question. Whichever side gets more than half of all votes cast is considered to have won.

WHY DID THE REFERENDUM TAKE PLACE?
Prime Minister David Cameron had promised to hold a referendum if he won the 2015 general election, in response to growing calls from his own Conservative party MPs and the UK Independence Party (UKIP), who argued that Britain had not had a say since 1975, when it voted to stay in the EU in a referendum. The EU has changed a lot since then, gaining more control over their daily lives, they argued. Mr Cameron had said: “It is time for the British people to have their say. It is time to settle this European question in British politics.”

WHO DID WANT THE UK TO LEAVE THE EU?
The British public was fairly evenly split, according to the latest opinion polls. The UK Independence Party, which won the last European elections, and received nearly four million votes – 13% of those cast – in May’s general election, campaigns for Britain’s exit from the EU. About half of Conservative MPs, including five cabinet ministers, several Labour MPs and the DUP were also in favour of leaving.

WHY DID THEY WANT THE UK TO LEAVE?
They believed Britain was being held back by the EU, which they said imposed too many rules on business and charges billions of pounds a year in membership fees for little in return. They also wanted Britain to take back full control of its borders and reduce the number of people coming here to live and/or work.
One of the main principles of EU membership is “free movement”, which means you don’t need to get a visa to go and live in another EU country. They also object to the idea of “ever closer union” and what they see as moves towards the creation of a “United States of Europe”.

WHO WANTED THE UK TO STAY IN THE EU?
Prime Minister David Cameron wanted Britain to stay in the EU. Sixteen members of his cabinet also backed staying in. The Conservative Party had pledged to be neutral in the campaign – but the Labour Party, SNP, Plaid Cymru and the Lib Dems were all in favour of staying in.
US president Barack Obama also wanted Britain to remain in the EU, as did other EU nations such as France and Germany. As mentioned above, according to polls, the British public seemed pretty evenly split on the issue.

WHY DID THEY WANT THE UK TO SAY?
Those who campaigned for Britain to stay in the EU say it got a big boost from membership – it would make selling things to other EU countries easier and, they argued, the flow of immigrants, most of whom are young and keen to work, could fuel economic growth and help  pay for public services. They also believed Britain’s status in the world would be damaged by leaving and that we were more secure as part of the 28 nation club, rather than going it alone.

WHAT HAS HAPPENED SINCE THURSDAY’S RESULTS WERE ANNOUNCED?
British voters voted for Leave by a margin of 52 percent to 48 percent. As the results were reported on Thursday evening, markets started to panic. The British pound fell from $1.50 earlier in the day to $1.35 in the early hours of Friday morning. That 10 percent drop brought the pound to its lowest value against the dollar since the 1980s.

Initially, David Cameron had vowed to continue in office even if British voters opted to Leave but by Friday morning his position had become politically untenable. He eventually resigned . Boris Johnson, a Conservative former mayor of London and Leave supporter, was considered a leading candidate to replace Cameron. However, it was Theresa Mary May, leader of the Conservative Party, who turned out to become the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.

Good Morning Pages 10/03/16
I love Monday mornings. I used to hate them but I have really grown fond of them over the years. I think the biggest reason I didn't like them so much is because I really didn't have a great time in school. I always felt like I could have been creating or doing something else. It would stress me out to be tied to a desk and trying to figure out things I was fairly sure I'd have no use for. I would play hooky and walk into the next town to the comic shop and see what was out. It would inspire me. I guess I just wasn't very inspired in school. I think some of this had to do with knowing very early on in my life that I wanted to be some sort of artist, then, more specifically, a comic artist and writer, a musician. I just knew I wanted to be involved in the arts. So I only acquired skills I thought would help me with that. Looking back, there could have been a few more things I could have used in the math department, though I'm awful at it.
By the time I got to my senior year, I was almost exclusively taking art classes, and in work study. So, I had one "normal" class in the morning, whatever that requirement was, then off to art for a solid chunk of the day, then I was allowed to leave school and go to work. I had figured out a way to drop out of gym class, so I didn't need to fill that requirement for the senior year. I could have probably used the exercise but I really couldn't be bothered.
So I entered the workforce early, I was already accepted into SVA by the time half the school year was over, so I was just phoning it in. I had actually entered the workforce earlier than that, at around 15 years old, where I worked for a catholic school uniform store. I handled the stock, and would often swipe patches and I bought myself a cardigan to wear to school. I wore that thing all the time.
College was eye opening. I think the greatest benefit to going was the first year, where the school required you to take every kind of art pretty much, even photography, where I got a D as a grade. I didn't take to the camera well but I took to drawing and abstract painting. I wasn't much good at sculpture either. I remember one of the assignments was that we had to construct a chair as an art piece. My work was so crummy that you couldn't sit in the chair at all, and I chose this horrible floral pattern for the upholstery. It was really a monstrosity. The only thing I created in sculpture class that I ended up liking was part of the assignment involving casting and carving plaster. I decided to make a "ghost log". I carved this large chunk of plaster into something that looked like a cartoon log, and then gave it a dark wash and sanded the surfaces to expose the white plaster. I even wrote a song about it.
"Deep in the woods, there was a ghost log...". And so on.
Today's assignments or possibilities: Umbrella Academy and Doom Patrol. With Umbrella, the 3rd series is worked out so it is only a matter of scripting the scenes and getting it off the Gabriel. With Doom, I need to dive into the next issue, but also plan out where the story is headed for the next year. I have a rough plan of this, as I'm flying a little bit by the seat of my pants, but it's time to bring it in. The core concepts and beats are there, though. The Umbrella Academy characters are old friends I know very well, but some of the Doom characters are new to me, though some of them I had been reading about for years, like Cliff Steele and Larry Trainor, so in a way they are old friends as well. Writing Cliff and Larry is very rewarding.
New York Comicon is this week. I have a pretty light schedule which is good, so I can stay on top of my scripts at night, or during the day when I don't have any obligations to fill. Will really be nice to walk around the city, though, as it has been some time. If I miss anything about New York City, it is the walking. I remember moving to LA and trying to walk places and it was almost impossible, and people look at you like there is something wrong with you for walking. "Nobody walks in LA" as the Missing Person song goes. It is really dead on. But NYC has an energy when you're walking around, it gives back to you. Now that Doom Patrol is out, I am excited to meet people to see what they think of it, see if they have latched on to any characters this early, or where they think it is headed. It has been nice keeping my head down and just working through things, though it is pretty solitary.
Alright, I'm off to work. Lots of stories and beats and characters to figure out.
Hope you have a great day, stay in school.

I find this book extremely useful for enriching your vocabulary, not just for standardized tests, but for overall purposes in reading, writing and of course, communicating verbally in an intelligent and effective manner.

The New SAT requires mastery of college level words, no matter what people may tell you. They disguise these words within passages, thus making it essential that you have a  rich vocabulary for good comprehension of the passages.

We hope you will read our thoughts about choosing high school courses that will provide a strong base for a liberal arts education. But in summary, we recommend:

The study of mathematics for four years, including the particular topics described
The study of science for four years: physics, chemistry, and biology, and preferably one of these at an advanced level
Frequent practice in the writing of expository prose
Various important secondary school subjects, such as art and music, are not specifically mentioned in our recommendations. Our Admissions Office chooses carefully from a broad range of applicants who seem to us to offer the most promise for future contributions to society. While the heart of the matter will always lie in academic promise, we prize candidates with special talents and with outstanding personal qualities; we are interested in students who excel in one or more extracurricular activities; and we seek a distinctive and diverse national and international student body.

Guys, I sat for my SAT I exam last year and I have some general advice for everyone from what I observed last time.
1) Bring your passport. You will not be allowed to sit for the exam under ANY CIRCUMSTANCES without the passport.
2) Carry at least 2 HB pencils with you. Try your best to keep the Answer Booklet as CLEAN as possible (very important). The machine which checks the scripts is extremely sensitive. That's why you should avoid using a 2B pencil.
3) Bring water and food. You'll get breaks after every 2 sections. Since the exam is very lengthy you don't want to get tired by the end of the exam (especially if you take the essay).
4) Wear warm clothing. At least make sure that you cover your feet. The exam halls can get really chilly and you don't want brain freeze in the middle of a CR section.
5) Bring your own watch if you can. Obvious reasons. Time slips away REALLY QUICKLY when the questions are hard.
6) If you have 5 mins left and see that you still have ~8 questions left to answer, first bubble in all your completed answers on the answer booklet and then try to answer the incomplete ones. Better to get 500 than 0.
7) For maths, if you don't get the question go Plug-and-play.
8) For reading, read the questions before the answers. They provide you with context and prepare yourself subconsciously so you can easily spot what you need to find.
Best of luck. Hope everyone aces it #SAT #LastMinAdvice

*Extra words and phrases #Olevel students should avoid writing in Section C*
   
1. Completely destroy –. You don’t need 'completely'. Ex: Babla completely destroyed his room. Better: Babla destroyed his room.

2. Connect together –. No need to use 'together'. Ex: Connect together the two wires. Better: Connect the two wires.

3. Different kinds –. Cut down the word 'different'. Ex: The chart lists five different kinds of animals. Better: The chart lists five kinds of animals.

4. Eliminate altogether –Skip writing 'altogether'. Ex: We should reduce or eliminate altogether speeding ticket fines. Better: We should reduce or eliminate speeding ticket fines.

5. Equal to one another –Lets not use 'to one another'. Ex: Aunkur and Kudus are equal to one another in size, but Aunkur is faster. Better: Aunkur and Kudus are equal in size, but Aunkur is faster.

Common errors to avoid in Physics: Post #1

We've all come across questions like "State why the waves are emitted as pulses instead of a continuous wave" when answering questions about echo location. I remember the answers in some of the very old mark schemes accepted answers such as "continuous waves create standing/stationary waves". However, be warned, the newer mark schemes strictly REJECT this answer. I still find many students writing this down blindly when it comes to answering these questions. This is incorrect.

The correct answer for this question is "so that the time taken for one pulse to return is measured before the next pulse is emitted". 

Also, other common mistakes I still find students making is that they forget to multiply the distance by 2 when they try to find the speed of the pulse. Since the time taken is the total time taken by the pulse to go and return, the distance traveled is also twice the distance, i.e. v=2d/t.

UPDATE: My interpretation:
The three noticeable aspects I could find was the use of appeal to emotions, imagery and anecdotes and reasoning. 
Carter starts with imagery, describing the area in concise details. This helps paint an image of the serene place in the mind of the readers/listeners.  This, with the imagery used in anecdote in the next para, acts as a base for him to persuade the audience that the wilderness should not be “consumed by a web..”, which might “disturb countless numbers of animals…” The audience will start empathizing with Carter as they start to imagine the horror of it all. 
The anecdote also serves to prove Carter’s credibility. The audience will then feel like he knows what he is talking about as he had first-hand experience with the place, and so cares about it. 
In many other places, the passage appeals to emotions of the reader. Carter evokes a sense of patriotism when he says "it is a symbol.." in para 8. This helps his cause by provoking American people to leave the area unscathed for the sake of the country. It also draws out sentiments. People will be more inclined to preserve what is left of the “remnant of frontier America”. The ending of para 7, where establishing oil drills is compared to “tearing open the heart” evokes sadness and horror in reader’s mind. Again the idea of taking away something that means a lot to the indigenous people (in para 6) makes the audience feel like they’re being selfish.
The third device he uses is reasoning or logos. This is most noticeable when he says that th Arctic Refuge might only provide 1-2% of the oil consumed by the country and that the American people can “conserve more than that amount by driving more fuel-efficient vehicles. This shows that there is a better alternative to the action, which will benefit not only few but many. The last line also serves as both an appeal to logic and also to emotions.

SICK - It is the less formal of the two words. It usually describes short-term diseases or ailments, like flu, and is commonly used to refer to a feeling of nausea. Think of a sick child who stays home instead of going to school or a person who feels sick to their stomach after a roller coaster ride.

Examples: 
Mosharraf Karim felt sick during the shooting of a tele-film and had to go home immediately.
After the roller coaster ride, Babu bhai felt ill.

ILL – It is more formal and is used to describe long- and short-term diseases or ailments. A person who is not in good health because of something serious like cancer or pneumonia might be said to be ill. On the contrary a person who is affected with a minor fever or cold can also be called ill. Like sick, ill also refers to a feeling of nausea.

Examples:
I was ill for a time few weeks ago, but I am fine now.
Momtaj looks ill. Farhan wonders what’s wrong with her.

*Ailments = an often persistent bodily disorder or disease; a cause for complaining.

CODING FOR ALL: THE HOWS AND THE WHAT'S:
So, you people are all passionate about computer programming and application development these days. Cool! Hats off! You guys are passionate about two topics which I used to fear at your age due to the inbuilt horror attached to the term "programming"! However, times have changed. Coding is now not just a skill that would glorify your curriculum vitae, it's a MUST! Personally, I would be surprised if the individual sitting next to me of my generation did not know how to code, regardless of his/her majors or interests.

As generations progress, each generation becomes subsequently advanced in technical fields than the previous generation. For example: I started making robots and embedded systems when I was in my Freshman Year at university; you guys are already doing that. Hats off again! :) 

One of the most common questions that starting coders ask: Where should I start? Well, there are countless possible paths. I would personally ask you to first get to know some computer fundamentals such as number systems, number arithmetic and basic structure of a computer. These would help you a lot when you start to code for real. Next, choose a programming language that you would use as the key to enter the world of programming. There are hundreds of computer languages out there, but I would strongly recommend that you start with C. C is kinda like a hub from which all other programming languages are accessible, although the reverse is not true. Once you learn C, you will easily get to learn other advanced programming languages; after all, the syntax of all programming languages are similar in one way or the other. 

I would recommend that you start with this course: https://alison.com/courses/Diploma-in-Programming-in-C
I had personally completed this course to supplement my basics in C programming during my Y-1 S-1 "Computer Programming" course. This course is free, easy to understand, self-paced and starts with the very basics, including the computer fundamentals required for programming as I had stated in the last paragraph. It requires no previous programming experience. You don't need to install any extra Integrated Development Environments (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integrated_development_environment) on your computer as the course features a web-based IDE where you can practice coding. It even features small tests that are marked automatically so that you can get to know how much you've learned. After completing this course, you will have a solid base in C programming, although you will not fully learn the different facets of C. Besides, if you are comfortable with books and want to learn all facets of C programming, go for Teach Yourself C by Herbert Schildt. If you want to learn programming in Bengali, go for Tamim Shahriar Subin's "Computer programming" (Link: http://cpbook.subeen.com/). If you want to learn programming in a childish but logical manner, here's a solution: https://hourofcode.com

If you are badass, you can create wonderful GUI (www.linfo.org/gui.html) games just by using C. However, using C for creating commercial applications and interactive programs would be a bad idea. Knowing C doesn't make you "productive" in the market. Furthermore, C doesn't encompass Object Oriented Programming (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object-oriented_programming), which is now fundamental to programming. So, what's the solution? Well, learn a new language! Now, since you are already an accomplished coder, you can choose which language you wanna learn, depending on your tastes and needs. For example, during my robotics and embedded systems project development, I found out the need for new applications that could interact with my projects. Thus, I started learning XML and Java, which seemingly are the languages used for android application development.
1. Interested in general software development? Aim for Python, C++ and Java.
2. Want to develop cool applications or softwares for Windows? C# and C++ will help you do it.
3. Want to develop android applications and games? Java & XML are the bosses.
4. An IOS freak eh? Swift is cool!
5. Nowadays, a lot of people are moving to web development. HTML, Javascript, PHP, CSS and Java are some of the languages you need to know.
6. Want to code robots and projects? Learn the Arduino, Processing, VHDL and MikroC.

Udacity hosts free tutorials and courses on all of the above mentioned programming languages. Since android programming is the new posh, here's a link to a really good course for beginner android developers: https://www.udacity.com/course/android-development-for-beginners--ud837
You do need some other tools like the JDK and Android Studio to start making android programs, all explained in the tutorial. If you want to make apps without coding, use the MIT App Inventor (appinventor.mit.edu). Although your applications won't be that cool, it's a good starting point.

Many of you want to make cool games. Game development is a challenge for beginner coders; since gaming involves a lot other than just programming, game developers usually work in groups consisting of designers, programmers, audio engineers, video editors, directors, producers and artists. However, making mini games with all those graphics and all is not impossible. Make sure you learn computer aided drawing using Adobe Illustrator, AutoCAD and Maya. Choose your platform and programming language and you are good to go.

There's no doubt that there's a great demand out there for mouse potatoes! Coding will open new realms in what you can do, limited only by your imagination. Programming just doesn't narrow you down to personal computers, you can even program hardware, embedded systems and robots! You can even create your own startup just by using coding skills. 

Failures come for free with coding. Even expert programmers rarely write bug-free codes when they develop applications. Hence, it's important not to give up and pull out your hair when you encounter errors in programming. Simply google up your problem; even Google "googles" when they get stuck! Programming requires dedication and patience, it's something you will never get to learn properly in your life. A degree in CSE will not necessarily land you in Google, while someone studying Mathematics may ace with her dedication, passion and coding skills. 

All right, so I think I've covered all the points except outsourcing, which I'll cover some day. Till then, good luck, and lets end this discussion in different "languages"! Observe how similar they are to each other.

1. Happy coding! (English)
2. printf("Happy coding!"); //C
3. System.out.println("Happy coding"); //Java
4. android:text="Happy coding" //XML
5. cout << "Happy coding!" //C++
6. Serial.println("Happy coding!"); //Arduino
7. print "Happy coding!" //python
